[Phase transition]Sharp Phase transitions  for the almost Mathieu operator

Artur Avila
CNRS UMR 7586, Institut de Mathematiques de Jussieu -
Paris Rive Gauche, Batiment Sophie Germain, Case 7012, 75205 Paris
Cedex 13, France  IMPA, Estrada Dona Castorina 110, 22460-320, Rio
de Janeiro, Brazil
artur@math.jussieu.fr

Jiangong You

Department of Mathematics, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, China
jyou@nju.edu.cn

Qi Zhou
Laboratoire de Probabilites et Modeles
aleatoires, Universite Pierre et Marie Curie, Boite courrier
188 75252, Paris Cedex 05, France

Department of Mathematics, Nanjing University, Nanjing 210093, China

qizhou628@gmail.com

It is known that the spectral type of the almost Mathieu operator depends in a fundamental way on both the strength of the coupling constant and the arithmetic properties of the frequency.  We study the competition between those factors and locate the point where the phase transition from singular continuous spectrum to pure point spectrum takes place, which
solves Jitomirskaya's conjecture in
. Together with, we give the  sharp
description of phase transitions for the almost Mathieu operator.

Main results

Main results

This paper concerns the spectral measure of the Almost Mathieu operator:
*
where  is  the phase,  is the frequency and  is  the coupling constant,
which has been extensively  studied because of its strong backgrounds in
physics and also because it provides interesting examples in spectral theory
. We will find  the exact transition point from singular
continuous spectrum to purely point spectrum of Almost Mathieu operator, thus solve  Jitomirskaya's conjecture in 1995(see also Problem 8 in).
More precisely, let  be the th convergent of  and
define
our main results are the following:

Let  with , then
we have the following:

If  then  has
purely absolutely continuous spectrum for all .
If  then  has
purely singular continuous spectrum for all .
If  then  has
purely point spectrum with exponentially decaying eigenfunctions
for a.e. .

Part (1) is proved by Avila, we state here just for
completeness. The cases  have been solved in previous works. Together with Theorem ,
one sees the sharp phase transition scenario of three types of the spectral measure. Moreover, the type of the spectral measure
is clear for all  except the line . See Figure 1 and Figure 2 below.

Theorem (3), also called Anderson localization (AL),  is optimal in the sense
that the result can not be true for  dense  . The
arithmetic property of  will influence the spectral measure.

Now we
briefly recall the history of this problem. By symmetry, we just need to consider the case . In 1980, Aubry-Andre
conjectured that the spectral measure of
depends on  in the following
way:

If  then  has
purely absolutely continuous spectrum for all , and  all .
If  then  has
pure point spectrum for all , and  all
.

If  then  has
purely absolutely continuous spectrum for all , and  all .
If  then  has
pure point spectrum for all , and  all
.

However,  Aubry and Andre overlooked the role of the arithmetic
property of .   Avron-Simon soon found  that by
Gordon's lemma,   has no
eigenvalues for  any ,  if . Since then,
people pondered how the arithmetic property of  influences
the spectral type and under which condition Aubry-Andre's
conjecture is  true.

When  is Diophantine (i.e. there exist   such that
for all ), and  is large enough, the operator has
pure point spectrum, and when  is
small enough, the operator has absolutely continuous spectrum
. The common feature of the above results is that
they both rely on KAM-type arguments, thus the largeness or
smallness of  depend on Diophantine constant
,  we therefore call such results  perturbative results.
Non-perturbative approach to localization  problem was
developed by Jitomirskaya, based on partial advance, she
finally  proved that if   is Diophantine,
has AL for all   and a.e. . It
follows from  the strong version of Aubry duality,
has purely absolutely continuous
spectrum for a.e. . Therefore, Jitomirskayaproved Aubry-Andre's conjecture in the measure setting, i.e. the
conjecture holds for almost every
.

Before Jitomirskaya's result, Last, Gesztesy-Simon,
Last-Simonhave already  showed that  has absolutely
continuous components for every ,  , so the conjecture in subcritical regime
still has some hope to be true, which was  also conjectured by Simon
. Recently, Avila-Jitomirskaya showed that if
is Diophantine, then  is purely
absolutely continuous for every . For
,  Avila-Damanik proved that the conjecture (1)
for almost every . The complete answer of
Aubry-Andre's conjecture (1) was provided by  Avila. One thus sees
that  is the phase transition point from absolutely continuous spectrum to singular spectrum.

Before Jitomirskaya's result, Last, Gesztesy-Simon,
Last-Simonhave already  showed that  has absolutely
continuous components for every ,  , so the conjecture in subcritical regime
still has some hope to be true, which was  also conjectured by Simon
. Recently, Avila-Jitomirskaya showed that if
is Diophantine, then  is purely
absolutely continuous for every . For
,  Avila-Damanik proved that the conjecture (1)
for almost every . The complete answer of
Aubry-Andre's conjecture (1) was provided by  Avila. One thus sees
that  is the phase transition point from absolutely continuous spectrum to singular spectrum.

The remained issue is Aubry-Andre's conjecture (2) when
is  Liouvillean.  People already knew that the spectral measure is pure point for Diophantine  and almost every phases, while it is purely singular continuous for  and all phase. So there must be phase transition when  goes from zero to infinity.  In 1995, Jitomirskaya
modified the second part of the Aubry-Andre's conjecture and conjectured the following
If , the spectrum is purely singular continuous for all .
If , the spectrum is pure
point with exponential decaying eigenfunctions for a.e. .
Thus  is conjectured to be
the exact phase transition point from  continuous spectrum to pure point spectrum. There are some partial results on Jitomirskaya's conjecture. By Gordon's lemma and the
exact formula of Lyapunov exponent, one can prove that
has purely singular continuous spectrum
for any  if , see also
Remark  for more discussions. For the pure point part,
Avila-Jitomirskaya showed that if
, then
has AL for a.e. .  You-Zhou proved that if  with  large enough (If one check carefully the proof, it already gives .), then the eigenvalues of   with exponentially decaying eigenfunctions are dense in the spectrum.  Readers can find more discussions on these two results  in section .
The  main contribution of this paper is to give a full  proof of Jitomirskaya's conjecture.

The remained issue is Aubry-Andre's conjecture (2) when
is  Liouvillean.  People already knew that the spectral measure is pure point for Diophantine  and almost every phases, while it is purely singular continuous for  and all phase. So there must be phase transition when  goes from zero to infinity.  In 1995, Jitomirskaya
modified the second part of the Aubry-Andre's conjecture and conjectured the following
If , the spectrum is purely singular continuous for all .
If , the spectrum is pure
point with exponential decaying eigenfunctions for a.e. .
Thus  is conjectured to be
the exact phase transition point from  continuous spectrum to pure point spectrum. There are some partial results on Jitomirskaya's conjecture. By Gordon's lemma and the
exact formula of Lyapunov exponent, one can prove that
has purely singular continuous spectrum
for any  if , see also
Remark  for more discussions. For the pure point part,
Avila-Jitomirskaya showed that if
, then
has AL for a.e. .  You-Zhou proved that if  with  large enough (If one check carefully the proof, it already gives .), then the eigenvalues of   with exponentially decaying eigenfunctions are dense in the spectrum.  Readers can find more discussions on these two results  in section .
The  main contribution of this paper is to give a full  proof of Jitomirskaya's conjecture.

We remark that the spectral type at the transition points  and  have not been completely understood so far. Partial results include the
following: in case , since the Lebesgue measure of the
spectrum is zero for every
,  by Aubry duality, we know  is purely singular continuous for a.e.
. In fact, Avila has proved more: if
is not rational w.r.t , then  is purely singular continuous. We remark that, by
Gordon's lemma, if , then  is purely  singular continuous for  and
every , we  include this  in Theorem (2).
Excluding or proving the existence of point spectrum in case that
is Diophantine is one of the major interesting problems for
the critical almost Mathieu operator. For the second transition
point , one knows almost nothing but purely
singular continuous spectrum  for a  set of
. The spectral type possibly depends on the finer
properties of approximation of , as conjectured by
Jitomirskaya in.

The  heart of Avila's global theory is his Almost Reducibility Conjecture(ARC), which says that subcriticality
implies almost reducibility.
Recall the cocycle  is called almost reducible, if
there exists , and a sequence  such that  converges to constant
uniformly in
For our purpose, we need this strong version of almost
reducibility, and  should be  chosen to be  with  arbitrary small.

Aubry duality

Suppose that the quasi-periodic Schrodinger operator

has an
analytic quasi-periodic Bloch wave  for some  and .
It is easy to see the Fourier coefficients of  satisfy the following  Long-range operator:

Almost Mathieu operator is the only operator
which is invariant under Aubry duality, and the dual of
is  .

Rigorous spectral Aubry duality was founded by
Gordon-Jitomirskaya-Last-Simon in, where they proved that
if  has pure point spectrum for a.e.
, then  has purely
absolutely continuous spectrum for a.e. . Readers can find more discussions about dynamical Aubry duality in section 4.

solution by periodic ones  along double periods.

Anderson localization

In this section, we  prove Theorem  (3). We re-state it as the following
Let  be such that
If   then the almost Mathieu operator
has Anderson Localization for a.e. .

Traditional method for Anderson Localization  is to prove the exponentially decay of Green function. Due to the limitation of the method,  Anderson Localization can be proved only for Liouvillean frequency with  so far . So there is still a gap between  and .

In this  paper, we develop a new approach  depending on the reducibility and  Aubry duality.
We will show that Theorem  can be obtained by
dynamical Aubry duality and the following full measure reducibility result:
Let  with ,  if
,  is
Diophantine w.r.t. , then  is
reducible.

In this  paper, we develop a new approach  depending on the reducibility and  Aubry duality.
We will show that Theorem  can be obtained by
dynamical Aubry duality and the following full measure reducibility result:
Let  with ,  if
,  is
Diophantine w.r.t. , then  is
reducible.

The dynamical Aubry duality was established by Puig,
who proved that Anderson
localization of the Long range operator  for almost every  implies reducibility of  for almost every
energies.    Conversely,  to deal with localization problem by reducibility was first realized by
You-Zhou in. However, in they can only prove the eigenvalues of  with exponentially decaying eigenfunctions are dense in the spectrum. The main issue remained is to prove  those eigenfunctions form a complete basis. The key point in this paper is that, we find  that the quantitative estimates in the proof of Theorem  actually provides
an asymptotical
distribution of the eigenvalues and eigenfunctions, which ultimately implies  pure point spectrum for almost every phases.
Compared with tradition localization argument, the price we have to pay is that we lose precise arithmetic  control on  the localization phases.
However, by this approach, one can indeed  establish a kind of  equivalence
between quantitative full measure reducibility of Schrodinger
operator (or Schrodinger cocycle) and Anderson
localization of its dual Long-range operator.
